Since this is the education forum, I will address education specifically.
 
 My opinion is that we are trying so hard to develop the full potential of everyone, that we are dragging everyone down a few pegs. It's seen in the language that we use: look at "No Child Left Behind". 
 
 When I went to school, the retarded kids or those who were otherwise slow either did not go to school, or were kept segregated in "special education" classes. The idea was, the kids who can learn and function at a high level were taught at a high level. Those who could not keep up were educated at a level they could handle. Let's face it, not every child out there has the potential to be a doctor or a lawyer or a rocket scientist. But it seems that now we try to treat every child as if they have this potential. We put the slow kids in the same classes that the higher functioning kids are in, and in turn drag the higher functioning kids down a little bit. If you have to "dumb it down" so everyone can keep up, we are not educating the higher functioning kids at the level that they are capable of. Decreased efficiency in the classroom is leading to a decreased level of education for our society as a whole. 
 
 I have spoken with several friends who I went to school with who are now teachers in the same schools that we went to back in the day. Most express frustration that they are forced to teach subjects at a markedly slower pace, and must continuously review and play catch-up with certain kids. Most will tell me that these are the kids that used to be in the "special classes". 
 
 I think it has a bit to do with the fact that we have become so PC that we are afraid to call a spade a spade. A slow kid is a slow kid. They will never be able to keep up with the majority. I'm all for providing education to everyone, but there are limitations to what you can do with some people. Should we be trying to turn all of our children into college material? No. Too Idealistic. Sounds good on paper, but it does not work in reality. Some kids were meant to re-tread tires, or make Big Macs, or pick up garbage. If that is the limit of their potential and they make it to that limit, then great for them. The world needs garbage collectors as much as it needs cardiothoracic surgeons. The only true waste is any child who does not strive to reach his full potential...whatever that may be. 
 
 It's simple triage folks, something I do in my job a lot. For those who do not know, 'triage' means: to sort. You have a limited amount of resources, and more patients (or students) than you can realistically help. You can attempt to save everyone, and in turn take attention away from the ones that need help the most and will most likely benefit the most from such attention. Or, you can realize that you cannot save everyone, and focus your resources towards those who are most likely to benefit from those resources.
